reviewText:
I originally purchased this game around the time that the sequel - Euro Truck Simulator 2 - was getting rave reviews. So why not buy the sequel? Because it was priced ten times more and - reviews aside - it seemed doubtful I would enjoy a game where I tediously drove a truck down highways avoiding traffic hauling cargo. At least, I thought,  the first game would give me an idea if I could even stomach the genre. And if it did, well only then would I consider paying the price for the sequel.

I was surprised out how engaging this game was. Perhaps because it stood in such stark contrast to all my other driving games (the Need For Speed series, Burnout Paradise, and similar), but there was something very relaxing  and enjoyable about driving between the lanes, making a point not to speed (much) and slam into other cars. It was almost zenlike. The graphics might not be particularly impressive but they got the point across, and the AI of the other cars was pleasantly non-aggressive. Figuring out the best routes to take and what cargos to deliver was not particularly challenging but it was relaxing, and a welcome change from the ordinary.

Sadly, that's not enough to sustain the game, at least not for me. Having advanced three tiers and played over twenty hours, the lack of variety is increasingly noticeable. All the highways and cities more or less look the same and the challenge is flat throughout. So while it was a wonderful ride up to this point, it wasn't enough to keep me playing until the nominal end" of the simulation. However
date: it /was/ enough to get me interested in the sequel
recommended: which apparently adds extra content and gameplay. And since that was the whole point of my playing this game in the first place
hoursPlayed: I consider it time and money well spent."

reviewText:
Bought in a bundle, this is worth the buck or two spent especially if you have an older PC to play it on.  ETS1 was a great idea and has been improved with the release of ETS2.  Pros and cons of this game...

Pros: Graphics not bad for its day and you can play a short run in 10-15 mins.  While getting in accidents, speeding, and running red lights gets you penalized, you can also play the jerk driver cutting other drivers off and hogging two lanes (which is almost a necessity if driving via keyboard).  Hint for new players--get your hazardous cargo cert ASAP so you can make more money faster.

Cons: A careful study of the road map shows this game was unfinished.  Back roads all over Poland, a few in Germany, and none anywhere else.  When driving around, you see several overpasses that were likely intended to be used for backroads, but were left unconnected to anything.  There are also loads of no-go zones in the cities, where AI vehicles can drive, but you cannot.  Another minor complaint; the physics of the truck in a cloverleaf turn allow for too much drift and jackknifing the truck is easy to do, even at low speeds.  I have learned to go real slow through these.

I am looking forward to playing ETS2, but if you have an older PC and/or a light wallet, you should give this game a whirl.

reviewText:
I really enjoy this game, even though people may think it's boring to keep driving back and fourth to different cities to only drop off cargoes in order to gain more money. Although there is less cities to drive to, I still enjoy it. I love the feeling to be able to drive properly, and have played 20 hours within 2 days due to being obsessed. I'm not saying the game is perfect, hell, the second game might not even be perfect (can't buy it since I have a Mac) however it still is fun.


I am quite big on graphics, and I have to admit this isn't so bad. The trucks/cars both look great and so does the interior of the trucks. You can either drive on manual or automatic which adds realism, and so does the various types of weather, time, and the rules of the road. Sound doesn't seem to be much of a problem, it has realistic car, weather, truck and engine noises.

Having to deliver more and more in order to gain more money, does take a lot of time. But this leads to the game being more addictive and actually worth it. However, if driving back and forth for a while isn't really your thing, this can become a problem, though I ensure it wont be when you actually try it out, and even better, unlock more places.


One thing that has annoyed me while driving around on here is how stupid the other drivers are. They either go the wrong way, beep at me when I am not doing anything wrong, and/or randomly brake when there was no need to which leads me into hitting them, which leads to me having to pay for hitting them. Adding pedestrians or animals would also be something which would make the game better (no I do not want to run them over)

Another thing is how the cities are extremely small, and only have up to 5-6 roads, which is bad for when you want to explore other places other than the highway. The sound is good, but not so great. It sounds like I'm driving ontop of the truck rather than inside (might be because the windows are always open for some reason) and the radio does not sound like it's actually coming out of a radio in the truck.


Honestly, I love this game even though it has some flaws which I have to live with, however those are probably fixed in ETS2. I recommend this game if you either have a older computer, have a Mac and cannot buy the second one (which is my case) or have a few cash left or is low on cash to spend it on this. An overall 6/10 from me.

reviewText:
As a person who has been a flight simulator addict for going on three decades now...  ( I cut my teeth on a green screen IBM bootleg copy of Pilot trainer circa 1988 )  I have often been skeptical of the 'ground runners.'  Trains, racing cars and boats all have the same singular fundementle flaw on the virtual stage.  Primarily that no matter how much you REALLY want it to be true, you are NOT going to get a realistic perspective view of ... well ... ANYTHING.  Land and city scapes will always be a generic  reflection of what you just saw and are about to see again.  SO; having established my rational for skepticesm, what am I doing here?  To put it plainly.  I'm cheap and my entertainment budget can be bought.  In short for $20 I got the whole euro-truken-paint joben collection.  You should too, hopefully here is why....

Pro # 1.

It's Europe and there isn't a freken war going on.  Well okay...  Actually about 2 thirds of Europe.  Sans the Balkans half of Italy and 1/3 of Iberia.  If you like Scandanavia.  You are officially S.O.L.  Rather Ironic in fact, considering that no less than half of the riggs you use in this series are models made in either Sweden or Norway.  Back to the point.  See something of the great old country without having to shoot it, dog fight over it or deal with Hitler or Napoleon.

# 2.

Beautifully simple.  Elegantly addictive.  I honestly went into this game with little if any knowledge of truck driving and after 6 hours that passed by like 30 minutes, I not only know something about the actual life style, I can also add that it was fun doing something curiously different than trying to beat a bunch of crazies to a finish line.

The one and only con I can come up with, is that the technology of it's day DOES let it down somewhat.  However; as I mentioned before I got the collection so I expect the second edition to be a bit more advanced.  Not only graphic wise but the over all control experience.  This first one is the best to learn on.  If you can get comfy with this one then you can graduate to more complicated challenges.

Jim

reviewText:
SCS Software specialised in making truck simulations from its humble beginnings back in 1997 with Hard Truck. From then on in, it concentrated on the American theater with its successful 18 Wheels of Steel series. This game, Euro Truck Simulator is the first of its kind hauling cargo throughout Europe and whilst it has the same feel as its cousin 18 Wheels of Steel, the simulation experience is not quite there as it does feel a little arcade. And if it wasn't for the career objectives, I probably enter this game into an early retirement.

The gameplay length is pretty much unlimited as there is no official ‘end’. You can literally go on forever however even the most dedicated truckie sim fan will eventually want to give up. However the game cleverly designed career progression chart, where you need to complete certain tasks to raise the ranks from being a novice to the master trucker. Five ranks in all and designed in a way to get the maximum usage for this game however it does take some considerable time to become the master. And because there are many feats (achievements) to earn, it provides you more reasons to play it so if it wasn't for those I'd probably give it a flick a lot sooner.

Full review here - http://www.gamespot.com/euro-truck-simulator/user-reviews/2200-12543344/

6 / 10

reviewText: Euro Truck Simulator is a 2008 truck simulation game created by SCS Software, using OpenGL, set in Europe. The player can drive across a depiction of Europe, visiting its cities, picking up a variety of cargos, and delivering them. Over 300,000 copies of the game have been sold in Europe. Its followup, Euro Truck Simulator 2, was released in 2012.\n\nPlayers choose their starting country, from Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom (V1.2 & V1.3 only). Initially players only have access to their starting country, except if it contains less than three cities. In this case one or more adjacent countries will be accessible as well. For example, starting the game in Italy or Switzerland, you get connection to the other for free. Then, players choose their first truck with a budget of €100,000.After this, players can start taking jobs from various fictitious companies and delivering cargo to various cities in their starting country to earn money. This money can then be spent on a new truck, upgrading the current truck, expanding the business to other countries and obtaining a license to drive flammables and chemicals.

reviewText:
This game will make you feel like you are on the road for long stretches of time... watching the daylight and weather and scenery come and go, pulling out of truck stops in the middle of the night, and rolling into town as the sun is rising.

There is a pretty serious time commitment here for such a simple game. Things like truck upgrades, unlocking new territories, and hazmat licenses are expensive relative to the amount you get paid for driving. You will be doing a lot of time-consuming long hauls to get a halfway decent truck and open up a few countries.

My recommendation would be to load some music files or even audiobooks into the game folder so that you can listen to them through the truck radio, or at least have something going in real life while you play. Otherwise you might get bored before too long just sitting there forever keeping your truck in the lanes... since you're not actually getting paid for it and all. But if you can find a way to multitask it can be a relaxing and fun time.

This game is fun and a great starting point if you want to get into SCS's Truck sim games as its quite smaller than ETS2 and has a few less features to worry about, this game is very similar to ETS2 with a few differences, for example in ETS2 you have to save up or take a loan to get your first truck but in this one you are made to buy your very first truck straight away and the way you take jobs is set differently too.

I have this game on my Tablet PC running a 1.66ghz atom processor and it runs smoothly with no visible issues, therefore it would be the better game to grab if you are wanting something with very low specifications for journeys on public transport or if you are a passenger on a road trip, there are a few flaws with the game but nothing thats too game breaking, if you have played ETS2 or even Scania truck driver simulator this game will feel outdated and primitive, however if you are looking to get into the series you cant go wrong with getting this game as part of the SCS deluxe package as you will get alot more value for your money.

all in all this game has aged very well and even to this days standards looks like a very well made indie game however you will feel dissapointed if you come from one of the newer games in the series, i will not go as far as to label this game as a high quality game but it is for the most part a decent playable game that can keep you going for endless ammounts of playing as you strive to work for bigger jobs or better trucks.

If you are looking for a highly detailed yet smoothly running truck simulator you cannot go wrong with this title, however if you want a more up to date feel with even better graphics, go for ETS2. if you cannot decide go for the deluxe bundle as you will get 5 titles and a whole bunch of DLC for ETS2.

reviewText:
I'm really not sure how this got to be popular. The driving feels far too heavy to be enjoyable, even for a simulator, and there are so, so many bugs in the physics engine and the AI's control of their vehicles for me to avoid running out of money while transporting goods.

The AI change lanes as fast as the cars on the freeways in GTA: San Andreas did - i.e. faster than your lumbering starter truck could ever hope to. They do so even when you are in the lane, which forces you to slam on the brakes lest you rear end them, leaving their car totally uninjured (i mean, really? we had destructable car models years and years ago) and immobile in the middle of the freeway. SImple curiosity brought me to Euro Truck Simulator; I kinda felt like trying a more realistic/unusual simulator (my only experiences with simulators has been Kerbal and Sim Cities).

What I got was pretty much what I expected.  Drive around, looking at environment as you try to do your best on deliveries; small goals with small challenges, that were momentarily rewarding.  The biggest problem I've found has been a lack of detailed roads and customization in your truck.  I'm not saying go crazy, but I never found any ways you could modify or trick out your truck at a small fee.  If they are there, it would have been nice to have the tutorial point you in that direction; this also kinda illustrates the problem with your truck/sleepiness/cargo status.  Didn't really make it clear what the ramifications are of not sleeping, following road rules, etc.

Beyond that, its moderately interesting.  I feel like only a select few types of people would get enough enjoyment out of this to legitimize the full price, but at $2.50, might be worth a pick up if you're curious.

Hearing about the wonders that the sequel to this game had, I wanted to see what the roots were. Having a outdated laptop that can't run much, the older game runs like gold on any computer of the recent 4 years or more. I experience some drops in frame rate here or there but not enough to say it is a problem.

The game itself is quite simple. Drive from here to there. Pick your haul and your destination. It is a simple concept that can have you sink hours into the game. Since this was the first of its kind, there number of options is limited and few compared to the sequel. You can't make your own company, and there is no RPG style leveling system. You just haul to get enough cash to upgrade your rig.

For what the game is, I adore it alot and plan to keep playing it. There is a steep curve in progress from your starting rig to a better one, but aside from that there is plenty of things to do. I can almost compare this to my time spent on Eve Online as a freighter for ore and other goods. I even play some Southern Rock on my ipod while I play this game.

This is a game that you want to kill time with. Is ETS2 better? Well, of course it is a sequel. However, if you want a simpler version or you have a sub-par gaming computer, buy this. If you are up for a more complex and demanding game, buy the sequel.

Where can I begin when describing this masterpiece?  From the moment you are transplanted into the cab of a powerful European Truck (not to be confused with those wussy American trucks) you will be hooked! It was VERY INTENSE.\nMy first route from Rome to Milan was almost cut short by a blue fiat that cut into my lane. I still hit the car, resulting in a small fine and no visible damage to my truck, which is again the utmost in realistic simulation action.\nEurope is painstakingly mapped, featuring realistic rocks and trees and two or more roads per country that connect both of the major cities. It is an endless source of wonderment that represents the pinnacle of modern video gaming.

reviewText:
This is the first driving simulator I've bought and I will say, it is very unique in a good way.
It is not a game, it is a simulator and with that in mind it ticks most of the boxes for realism.
Graphics are not great by todays standards, however, it will run smoothly on older PCs and low spec laptops.
It can be stressful (just like real truck driving) with an emphasis on obeying traffic laws, fuel consumption, maintenance & damage of truck etc..

I like:
The level of detail for cockpit view and the realism of controls -
(headlights, wipers, cruise control, shifting through the gears)
Playing your own music collection through the truck stereo.
Day/Night, weather and traffic.

I don't like: The repetition of long hauls on mostly boring highways (but it is a simulator!)
You have to play for hours and hours to earn very little cash (and spend your profits wisely)

Addictive, satisfying but stressful.

*I use a keyboard and mouse for controls but would recommend using a game pad controller because the keyboard is very difficult for steering and throttle accuracy.
